abstract.t: This is a list of frequently asked questions regarding xml2rfc, a tool that can be used to create Internet-Drafts or RFCs.
This FAQ is for version 3 of xml2rfc; the vocabulary has been changed significantly from version 2. For guidance on version 2, please see the FAQ for xml2rfc v2.

note.name: Note to Readers
note.t: Please send suggestions or corrections to the xml2rfc mailing list. Source code for this document can be found at .

section.name: The Basics
What is xml2rfc?
section.t: xml2rfc is a tool that lets you convert an XML source file into a text, HTML, PDF, expanded XML file, or various other options. It is available from https://xml2rfc.tools.ietf.org as a web-based service or for download. Version 3 of the tool adds new features and will be used by the RFC Editor to create RFCs. The current version is here: .

section.name: Why should I use xml2rfc?
section.t: It's an easy way to create an Internet-Draft in the proper format. It handles boilerplate text and reference text. The HTML and PDF output formats have new features (such as including SVG figures and non-ASCII characters), and the source file can be used for metadata extraction. Also, the RFC Editor will make use of your source file. (For background, see the RFC Format FAQ.)

section.name: How much XML do I need to know?
section.t: You need the essentials. XML uses start and end tags, which are nested and matching, and they are case-sensitive. See "XML basics" in for more details.

section.name: Creating a Draft
What's the recommended setup?
section.t: You have several choices when getting started with xml2rfc, such as:

ul.li: Use the tool on the web () or install it locally ().
Use the citation libraries online or maintain a local copy.
Edit in your favorite editor or use an XML editor.

section.t: There are also tools available to let you edit non-XML source and then compile it to xml2rfc XML:
If you intend to host your draft in git or on Github, see for advice.

section.name: Where can I get a template?
section.t: Several templates for xml2rfc v2 are available from https://tools.ietf.org/tools/templates. They include templates for a generic draft (e.g., draft-davies-template-bare.xml), as well as for a draft containing a MIB (e.g., mib-doc-template-xml.txt). They have not yet been updated for v3; when some are available, they will be posted in the same directory.

section.name: How can I do it without a template?
section.t: You can convert an existing XML file from the v2 vocabulary to the v3 vocabulary using xml2rfc --v2v3 (see ), and go from there. Use <t> elements for paragraphs, and <figure><artwork> elements for figures. Use <![CDATA[ ... ]]> within <sourcecode> or <artwork> elements that contain the less than character (<). (See for more information.)
To get a citation like "[RFC2119]", use <xref target="RFC2119"/>. See for more information.

section.name: How do I use the rfc element to create an Internet-Draft?
section.t: Use the category attribute to indicate the intended category of your draft, where std is Standards Track, info is Informational, exp is Experimental, bcp is Best Current Practice, and historic is Historic.
Use the submissionType attribute to indicate the intended document stream, where the value can be IETF, IAB, IRTF, or independent.
See for information about the ipr attribute.
Use the docName attribute to indicate the filename.

If the document potentially updates or obsoletes any RFCs, use the updates and obsoletes attributes to indicate the relevant RFC numbers. For Internet-Drafts, this information will be displayed in the header, followed by "(if approved)".
For example, putting it together:
section.sourcecode: <rfc category="info" submissionType="IETF" ipr="trust200902" docName="draft-ietf-wgname-topic-00" updates="1234, 1235" obsoletes="1236" sortRefs="true">
section.t: Note: The attributes number and seriesNo will be added by the RFC Editor if your draft is approved for publication as an RFC.
Note: Some features that used to be processing instructions (in v2) are now attributes of the rfc element (in v3) -- for example, sortRefs and symRefs.

section.name: Using References
How do I put in a reference?
section.t: A set of online citation libraries are maintained on xml2rfc.tools.ietf.org. They include citations for RFCs, Internet-Drafts, and documents produced by the W3C and 3GPP, among others.
To make use of the citation libraries, use an xi:include in the references section as follows.
For an Internet-Draft, the citation filename uses the draft string. For example:
Preferably, use the citation libraries when possible. However, another option is to include the complete reference element (see ). Here's a template of a reference element:
section.sourcecode: <reference anchor="" target=""> <front> <title></title> <author initials="" surname="" fullname=""> <organization /> </author> <date month="" year="" /> </front> <seriesInfo name="" value="" /> </reference>
section.t: All are cited textually in the same manner -- by using xref elements where the target corresponds to the anchor of the reference element, e.g., <xref target="RFC2119" />. The anchors for RFCs are "RFCNNNN" (4 digits, using leading zeros) and the anchors for Internet-Drafts are "I-D.<name without "draft-" or the version number>".

section.name: How do I insert the full reference?
section.t: There are several ways to insert the full reference element from the citation library:

ol.li: Keep a local copy of the citation libraries. They are available from https://xml2rfc.tools.ietf.org.
Use a browser to look it up online, e.g., , and copy the page source.
Run xml2rfc with output mode set to XML. The output will include the complete reference elements for any entities and includes.

section.name: How do I change the reference tags from symbolic to numeric, i.e., from [RFC2119] to [1]?
section.t: In the rfc element, set the attribute symRefs="no" for symbolic references. This makes reference tags be numeric, e.g., [1], instead of symbolic, e.g., [RFC2119].

section.name: How do I get the references listed in alphabetical order?
section.t: In the rfc element, set the attribute sortRefs="yes". Note that sortRefs only has an effect if symRefs="yes".

section.name: How do I link to multiple sections within a document (e.g., 'see Sections 3 and 4')?
section.t: Use <xref> with the format attribute. For example, assuming the anchors for the relevant sections match the targets:

section.t: Use <xref> with sectionFormat="bare". For example:

section.name: Using Lists
How do I get different kinds of lists?
section.t: For bulleted lists, use the <ul> element.
For an empty list (indentation only), use the <ul> element with empty="true".
For definition lists (a.k.a. hanging lists in xml2rfc v2), use the <dl> element. See .
For numbers or letters, use the type attribute of the <ol> element; examples below.
For full details, see .

ul.li: type="I" --> I, II, III, ...
type="i" --> i, ii, iii, ...
type="a" --> a, b, c, ...
type="A" --> A, B, C, ...
type="REQ%d:" --> [See .]

section.name: How do I get a list like (1), (2), (3) or (a), (b), (c)?
section.artwork:
(1) (2) is <ol type="(%d)"> (3)
(a) (b) is <ol type="(%c)"> (c)
REQ1: REQ2: is <ol type="REQ%d:"> REQ3:

section.name: How do I get continuous numbering in a list that is split by text (or across sections)?
section.t: Set the group attribute to the same value for each <ol> element. For example:
section.sourcecode:
1. do a
  2. do b
Here is text in between.
  1. do c
  2. do d
Here is more text in between.
  1. do e
  2. do f
section.t: yields:
Here is text in between.
Here is more text in between.

section.name: How do I get indentation? or How do I use definition lists?
section.t: Use a <dl> element (definition list), where each <dt> (term) in has a corresponding <dd> (description).
For example:
section.sourcecode:
<dl> <dt>Unassigned:</dt> <dd>Unused and available for assignment via documented procedures.</dd>
<dt>Reserved:</dt> <dd>Not to be assigned. Reserved values are held for special uses, such as to extend the namespace when it become exhausted. Reserved values are not available for general assignment.</dd> </dl>
section.t: yields:

dl.dd: Unused and available for assignment via documented procedures.
Not to be assigned. Reserved values are held for special uses, such as to extend the namespace when it become exhausted. Reserved values are not available for general assignment.

section.t: Note: The appearance is slightly different in the text output.
Use newline="true" to get a line break after the term. For example:
section.sourcecode:
<dl newline="true"> <dt>Unassigned:</dt> <dd>Unused and available for assignment via documented procedures.</dd>
<dt>Reserved:</dt> <dd>Not to be assigned. Reserved values are held for special uses, such as to extend the namespace when it become exhausted. Reserved values are not available for general assignment.</dd> </dl>
section.t: yields:

dl.dd: Unused and available for assignment via documented procedures.
Not to be assigned. Reserved values are held for special uses, such as to extend the namespace when it become exhausted. Reserved values are not available for general assignment.

section.name: The Finer Points
What is CDATA for?
section.t: A CDATA block is left alone by xml2rfc. It does not try to parse XML inside of a CDATA block. (For example, if a figure contains "<", you don't have to use <) So it is especially good for when there are XML examples in the document.

section.name: Miscellaneous
How do I know if my XML is valid?
section.t: xml2rfc validates it. Also, you can run rfclint: .

section.name: Can I get a different kind of HTML output?
section.t: Yes, rfc2629.xslt by Julian Reschke provides a different kind of HTML output than the HTML output mode of xml2rfc. See "Transforming RFC7749-formatted XML through XSLT" for more information.

section.name: Is there a tool that will turn my text file into an XML file (i.e., id2xml)?
section.t: Yes, id2xml is available here: . It is available as a web service on .

section.name: New with v3
How do I convert my XML file from v2 to v3 so I can make use of the new features?
section.t: On the command line: xml2rfc --v2v3 inputfile.xml. You can use the --add-xinclude option to replace RFC and I-D reference elements with the appropriate xi:include element.
Or, using the web service (), select "Output format: convert v2 to v3 XML".
After converting it to v3, please see .

section.name: After converting an XML file from v2 to v3, what further updates might be needed for the v3 XML file?
section.t: You may want to do the following (for the sake of generating good output and having a semantically accurate XML file):

ul.li: Is it really a list? Or should indentation be added in another manner, e.g., <blockquote>.
If so, should it be <dl>, <ul>, or <ol>? See .
Should it be <sourcecode>? If so, what type? See .
Should it be a table? See .
Search for URLs; should these be <eref>? See .
Look for equations or other text where new features may improve clarity. See .
Search for hardcoded citation tags (e.g., [RFC5234]) and update to <xref>s. See .
Search for "section" and make a link for any section number in RFCs and I-Ds (using <xref> with section and sectionFormat attributes). See .
Review postal addresses of authors; has each address been tagged correctly?

section.name: What are the new features with v3?
section.t: Some highlights are including Unicode characters, text formatting, and SVG diagrams. For complete details, see .

section.name: How do I generate SVG that will be accepted in an RFC?
section.t: You can check your SVG file against the SVG Tiny 1.2 spec on the experimental page (), and a script called svgcheck is available here: .
For more information, see and Tips on creating SVG files.

section.name: How do I include SVG in my document?
section.t: From RFC 7991:

blockquote.t: There are at least five ways to include SVG in artwork in Internet-Drafts:

ul.li: Inline, by including all of the SVG in the content of the element, such as: <artwork type="svg"><svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/ svg...">
Inline, but using XInclude (see Appendix B.1), such as: <artwork type="svg"><xi:include href=...>
As a data: URI, such as: <artwork type="svg" src="data:image/ svg+xml,%3Csvg%20xmlns%3D%22http%3A%2F%2Fwww.w3...">
As a URI to an external entity, such as: <artwork type="svg" src="http://www.example.com/...">
As a local file, such as: <artwork type="svg" src="diagram12.svg">

section.name: How do I get bold, italics, or a fixed-width font?
section.t: Use

ul.li: <em> for italics,
<strong> for bold, and
<tt> for fixed-width font.

aside.t: Note: in the text output, <em> yields underscores, <strong> yields asterisks around the text, and <tt> yields quotation marks.

section.name: How do I get subscript and superscript?
section.t: Use <sub> for subscript, and <sup> for superscript.
Example (using text from RFC 6330):

ul.li: x0 = (y + i) mod 28
x1 = (floor(y / 28) + i) mod 28
x2 = (floor(y / 216) + i) mod 28
x3 = (floor(y / 224) + i) mod 28

section.name: Do I have to use the bcp14 element each time a keyword (e.g., "MUST") appears in my document?
section.t: It is not a MUST, but it makes the usage more clear.

section.name: What is the best way to print a hard copy?
section.t: Print the PDF.

section.name: How do I download the XML source files for all RFCs?
section.t: The source files of RFCs have changed over time. Most RFCs have NROFF source files; sometimes an XML file has been archived. You can request an XML source file directly from rfc-editor@rfc-editor.org. For RFCs created after the transition to xml2rfc v3, the XML files will be available for bulk download from .

abstract.t: This document defines the "xml2rfc" version 3 vocabulary: an XML-based language used for writing RFCs and Internet-Drafts. It is heavily derived from the version 2 vocabulary that is also under discussion. This document obsoletes the v2 grammar described in RFC 7749.
